sn:content.value:
# About quantizr

SubNode is a sharing, publishing, and collaboration platform, with social media features, wiki-like features, and file sharing features. It's like a virtual file-system "in the cloud" that you can publish onto, search, and view timelines (rev-chron) of, etc.

## What is SubNode?

* SubNode is built on a tree-structure like file-systems are.
* Users navigate the app by browsing this tree, searching it, posting to it, etc.
* A Node is the fundamental unit of publishing (like a tweet, etc)
* Nodes can contain any number of other sub-nodes. 
* Each Node automatically has it's own unique URL, and can be shared with others or kept private.
* The tree can be searched, and timelines displayed for any node of interest.
* Images or other files can be attached to any node and will be displayed there.
* Infinite numbers of specific threaded discussions can take place because the way you 'reply' to (i.e. add comments to) any node is simply by attaching a sub-node (i.e. a child node) directly under it.

### IPFS

All of the above bullet points are also fully compatable with the statement that in the near future SubNode is going to be an IPFS browser, with the ability to read/write onto the IPFS Web, and also do full-text searcho on IPFS data. There is no IPFS code yet in SubNode, however, and the current version only reads/writes to MongoDB.

## User Guide

This node is organized exactly like the menu on the left-hand side of the application and describes what each function does. 

The green "Open" button on each node is how you drill down into that branch of the tree. To come back up the tree use the "Up Level" button (on top right of page). SubNode doesn't yet support the back button, for going back, so the "Up Level" is important for that.

# Links

This is a menu of links to specific special-purpose nodes in the app, or sometimes to other separate web pages on the internet.

## Your Home

Takes you to your own personal root sub-node, which is the top level root of all the content you have created under your account. Essentially this node holds your entire account data, and everything you've created.

## SubNode Home

Navigates you to the main landing page of SbNode.com

# Edit

Used to edit content on the tree. You can create, edit, and delete nodes, as well as do cut-and-paste types of manipulations involving nodes or entire branches of the tree.

## Create

Creates a new sub-node under the currently selected node. Depending on what you might be doing this new node could be a comment to some post, a reply in a conversation chain, or simply a new paragraph in a document you are writing. Nodes are just arbitrary content, and this Create function one one way to create a new node.

## Rename

All nodes can optionally be given textual name by the owner of the node. 

The main reason you would do this is to activate a friendly URL (permalink) that you can share on the web. You could make the node public (via Share menu) and then share the link publicly, or you can alternatively share with just certain specific people, in which case the link will only work for them.

This menu item brings up a dialog that lets you enter a name for the node.

Once a node has a name assigned you can use the "View -> Show URL" function to see what it's URL will be once shared. Until shared that URL will work but only for the owner of the node.

## Cut

Cuts the selected nodes from their current location, pending your clicking on "Paste" to put them in a new location.

## Undo Cut

Undoes the last cut action, restoring the node(s). Nodes are not actually moved until you do both a Cut and a Paste.

## Paste Inside

After you select some nodes and click "Cut" menu, you then can use the "Paste Inside" operation to move the nodes to the new location. That is, the nodes will be moved to the new location on the tree underneath the node you have selected at the time you click "Paste".

NOTE: "Paste Inline" pastes nodes adjacent to (siblings of) where you have selected, and "Paste Inside" instead pastes nodes as children of the selected node.

## Paste Inline

After you select some node and click the "Cut" menu, you use the "Paste Inline" operation to paste them at a specific location on the tree. That is, the nodes will be moved to the new location on the tree adjacent to the node you have selected at the time you click "Paste"

NOTE: "Paste Inline" pastes nodes adjacent to (siblings of) where you have selected, and "Paste Inside" instead pastes nodes as children of the selected node.

## Clear Selections

Clears out any node selections you have made, using the check-boxes at the upper left of each node.

## Delete

Permanently deletes one or more nodes. Use the node check-boxes (at upper left of any node) to select which ones you want to delete and then click this delete menu item to delete them.

# Move

Move nodes to new locations on the tree. You can move around individual nodes one at a time, or entire branches of the tree. This app works much like a file-system in this regard, similar to how you can move files and folders in a file-system.

## Move Up

Moves the selected node up in the ordered list of children under its parent. Another way to think of it, is that this node will have switched places with the node above it. It went one place higher up in the list.

## Move Down

Moves the selected node down in the ordered list of children under its parent. Another way to think of it, is that this node will have switched places with the node below it. It went down by one position in the list.

## Move To Top

Moves the selected node to the top position above all other nodes at its level under the parent.

## Move To Bottom

Moves the selected node to the bottom position below all other nodes at its level under the parent.

# Attach

Allows you to upload and attach arbitrary files or images to any node. If you attach an image it will show up inline in the document. Other types of files will not necessarily be displayed inline in the browser but users can click to download them.

## Upload from File

Uploads a file from your own local computer onto the node you have selected.

## Upload from URL

Allows you to upload a file using some existing internet URL (like the URL for an image, or PDF file, etc. anywhere on the internet that is publicly available). When you upload a file this way the file never goes to your computer, because you are basically instructing the SubNode server to go get the file and store it for you on on the remote server's node. 

This is the quickest/simplest way to share an online image (or other file) with someone, because you skip the step of downloading it just for the purpose of re-uploading it.

## Delete Attachment

This will delete whatever file you have attached to the currently selected node.

# Share

Any node you own can be shared with specific other users, or made public to everyone. When you share a node, all the SubNodes underneath it also will be shared automatically without you having to specifically share them. That is, sharing a node also makes its children shared, and the children of those children, etc.

## Edit Node Sharing

Edits the sharing settings for this node (and all subnodes underneath, recursively). You can share any of your nodes with one or more other people, or with the public (everyone).

# Search

Runs a full-text search under the node you have selected. You can search by all content or just do a search against tags.

## Content

To find text, under any branch of the tree, you can select a tree node and the click "Search -> Content". This will let you enter the text to find and a search will be performed *only* underneath the selected node. To search *all* of your data you would click "My Info" (Upper right of page), which takes you to your account root node, and select that node before doing the search.

## Tags

This search function works the same way as the "Content" search, except it will only search for nodes that have tags matching the search term.

# Timeline

You can view a timeline for any node. The timeline of a node is defined as a reverse-chronological listing of all the children under that node (and children of children, etc). You get a flat list of every node under the entire branch of the tree that you selected, as one big ordered list of nodes. You can choose to order by the date the nodes were created or the date the nodes were last edited.

From the the timeline listing panel you can also jump directly from any node in the timeline to the actual place on the tree (full tree context) where that node is located, with a single click.

## Created

Displays the timeline of a node, based on each node's creation timestamp.

## Modified

Displays the timeline of a node, based on each node's creation timestamp.

# View

Allows you to configure how you want the page to look, by configuring how each node gets layed out on the page, and what other metadata for each subnode you want to be viewing. Going with the least amount of settings creates a more clean look where the page looks more like a simple document.

## Toggle Properties

Each node consists of a set of properties and values (key/values). If you turn on the properties display option, then you can see all the information including some internal technical information and metadata that the system stores for each node.

## Refresh

SubNode is a SPA (Single Page Application) so you don't normally do a browser refresh to force a reload of the page, because that causes a reload of the entire application. However, if you want to be sure your current page is displaying the latest information from the database, you can use this refresh to cause the app to refresh the data you are viewing. Normally you would never need to do this, unless you are viewing a branch of the tree where you think others might be editing or adding nodes.

## Show URL

Each node is uniquely accessible (addressable) online on the web, and has it's own unique URL automatically. Only the owner of any given node and people that owner has shared the node with can view that URL. 

To see the external URL of a node, just click the node, and then choose "Show URL". By default each node will have an automatically generated number that defines the unique part of it's URL, but if the node's owner has given the node a specific text name then that name will be usable as an additional URL that points to this node.

# Tools

Currently the 'tools' available are Import and Export, allowing you to save information into and out of your tree to your local drive.

## Export

This is an admin-only function (that ordinary users cannot access) that exports the selected node content into various different allowed export formats. No downloading takes place, at the time of the export. The export file is created on the server file-system in the admin folder, that has been designated for this purpose. The ZIP file format is the one that allows re-importing back into the system at some future time.

## Import

Admin-only function that imports a file that was previously exported using the export function. To import only zip files that were exported by SubNode, may be re-imported back in. There is a specific JSON formatted file for each node that will exist in the special ZIP file.

# Account

Allows you to manage your own account. Change your perferences, password, email, close account, etc.

## Preferences

Opens the user preferences dialog.

## Change Password

Takes you to the change password dialog.

## Manage Account

Opens the account management dialog. The only account management function that currently exists is the option to close the account.

## Getting Started: How to Create and Publish a Node

The following steps creates a new node that you can share and make public, or share privately with a specific person.

## What is SubNode used for...

The core concept of this app is that users can create Trees of content consisting of Nodes. Nodes are similar to Twitter Tweets, Facebook Posts, or Mastodon Toots. 

Each "social media" app generally has it's own noun (or name) for the fundamental unit of content, and for SubNode this noun is "Node". The word "node" has been used by software developers for decades to represent the elements on a tree, and this is why the app itself is called SubNode.

Because of this flexible tree structure, SubNode can serve as a wiki editor, blogging platform, corporate collaboration tool, document authoring app, or social media posting app, to name a few use cases. Just like your operating system doesn't assume anything about what's in its folders, SubNode also doesn't care what your Nodes represent.

This powerful tree-based hierarchy allows for better organization of information, fine-grained sharing of specific content to specific users, built-in full-text search, timelines (rev-chron), copy/paste tree management, file attachments, etc.

## IPFS (Interplanetary File System)

The next version of SubNode will have features to read and write to the IPFS Internet, which is the new "distributed web" everyone has been talking about recently. IPFS is what is going to "take back the web" from the monopolies (FACEBOOK+GOOGLE+TWITTER) that currently get to control the lives of us all, and control what we can see, what we can hear, and even censor what we can say. 

It's beyond the scope here to describe anything further about IPFS, but the main thing you need to know about IPFS is that it's built on the same technology as Blockchains, and is distributed and uncensorable, just like Bitcoin. You can think IPFS as that "new internet" everyone has been talking about, and it's actually very real.

Currently SubNode is using only MongoDB for all data storage, but once the IPFS layer has been added, the MongoDB architecture of SubNode will be used as a cache and index for doing full-text search, sorting, and backing application-layer data storage. So the way to think of SubNode is that it will be a participant on the IPFS web, and will be usable as a way to browse the IPFS web.

### Step 1. Enable Editing Mode

* Log into your account.
* Click the Home button at top right of page, to go to your root node.
* Click the "Edit Mode" button (pencil icon) at upper right.

### Step 2. Create the Node

* Be sure to click on your root node, so that you see the red colored left edge of it highlight which tells you this is now your 'selected' node.
* To create a new node, click the "new" button at the top of the selected node. This creates a new node underneath the selected node.

### Step 3. Enter the Text (your actual post)

* You should now be seeing the Edit Node dialog where you can enter some content text for your post/node. Markdown is allowed.
* When you are done click "Save" and the editing dialog goes away and you will see your new node on the tree.

### Step 4. Attach an Image

* Click on you our new node to be sure it's highlighted (again, it should have a red colored left edge when selected)
* In the menu on the left choose "Attach -> Upload from File".
* Click in the rectangle on the upload dialog.
* Select some image file from your computer.
* Click the "Upload" button.
* Your image should now appear on the node along with the markdown you added.

### Step 5. Find the URL of your new Node (for sharing)

* In the menu on the left click "View -> Show URL"
* The dialog that appears will show the URL that will display just your new node, and allow navigating to anything that might be below it on the tree.
* So far no one but you will be able to view that node, so next, let's share it so others can see it.

### Step 6. Share node to the Public

* Again select the node by clicking on it.
* From the menu, click "Share -> Edit Node Sharing", to display the dialog that lets you control who can see the node.
* Click "Share to Public" button to add a privilege of readonly to everyone (even users without an account can see public nodes)
* Click "Save" button next to enable your changes.
* Now you should see that you can view the Node URL (from above), even after you logout, and all other web browsers can see it also, even if they aren't currently a user of SubNode.

## About Sharing nodes and 'conversation threads'

If you had wanted to share this node with just one or more specific people, and have a private conversation 'under it', you could have just selected "Share with Peson", in the Sharing dialog, and entered the username(s) of those people. After doing so you would then send them the URL, and they would be able to see it and also attach their own nodes under it, which would be like "replies" to it. That is: the way you 'reply' to a post in SubNode is by adding a node *underneath* the one you are replying to. A reply to that reply then becomes another node under that one, so it ends up forming a chain. Also there is an email notification that goes out to you whenever someone adds a node under one of your nodes, so that you know to go back and reply to their reply, etc. (have an ongoing conversation)
